conclusion: The graph shows the relationship between volume V and temperature T for an ideal gas.
State A: pressure pA = p0, temperature TA = T0, volume VA = V0 (from graph).
State B: volume VB = V0, temperature TB = T0 (from graph).
State C: extension line of BC passes through origin O.
Line segment AB is parallel to the V-axis.
For an ideal gas, the relationship between pressure (p), volume (V), and temperature (T) is pV = nRT.
Since we're dealing with a fixed mass of gas, n and R are constants, so pV ‚àù T or pV/T = constant.
State C: (TC, VC) - these are unknown.
Since the extension of line BC passes through the origin, states B, C, and O lie on the same straight line.
The equation of a line through points (0,0) and (T0, 2V0) can be written as V/T = 2V0/T0.
Since C lies on the line from origin through B, V_C/T_C = 2V0/T0.
From the graph, it appears that VC = V0/2 (half of VA).
Substituting VC = V0/2 into the line equation gives V0/2/T_C = 2V0/T0.
Solving for TC gives T_C = T0/4.
The temperature at state C is TC = T0/4, which is one-fourth of the temperature at state A.
